sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• patients must receive a meningococcal vaccine at least 2 weeks prior to initiation of eculizumab therapy, and revaccinations should be performed according to current guidelines
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome, Atypical: 900 mg by IV infusion over 35 minutes every 7 days for the first 4 weeks, then 1200 mg by IV infusion for the fifth dose 7 days later, then 1200 mg by IV infusion every 14 days thereafter
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria: 600 mg by IV infusion over 35 minutes every 7 days for the first 4 weeks, then 900 mg by IV infusion for the fifth dose 7 days later, then 900 mg every 14 days thereafter

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• patients must receive a meningococcal vaccine at least 2 weeks prior to initiation of eculizumab therapy, and revaccinations should be performed according to current guidelines
  • (paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria) safety and efficacy not established for patients under 18 years of age
  • (atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome) safety and efficacy not established for patients under 2 months of age
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome, Atypical: (40 kg or greater) 900 mg by IV infusion over 1 to 4 hours every 7 days for the first 4 weeks, then 1200 mg by IV infusion for the fifth dose 7 days later, then 1200 mg by IV infusion every 14 days thereafter
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome, Atypical: (30 kg to less than 40 kg) 600 mg by IV infusion over 1 to 4 hours every 7 days for the first 2 weeks, then 900 mg by IV infusion for the third dose 7 days later, then 900 mg by IV infusion every 14 days thereafter
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome, Atypical: (20 kg to less than 30 kg) 600 mg by IV infusion over 1 to 4 hours every 7 days for the first 3 weeks, then 600 mg by IV infusion every 14 days thereafter
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome, Atypical: (10 kg to less than 20 kg) 600 mg by IV infusion over 1 to 4 hours for the first dose, then 300 mg by IV infusion for the second dose 7 days later, then 300 mg by IV infusion every 14 days thereafter
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome, Atypical: (5 kg to less than 10 kg) 300 mg by IV infusion over 1 to 4 hours every 7 days for the first 2 weeks, then 300 mg by IV infusion every 21 days thereafter

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• adverse reactions: in adults the infusion rate may be slowed or stopped if an adverse reaction occurs, but the total infusion time should not exceed 2 hours
  • plasmapheresis or plasma exchange (most recent dose 300 mg): supplemental dose of 300 mg by IV infusion over 35 minutes within 60 minutes after each plasmapheresis or plasma exchange
  • plasmapheresis or plasma exchange (most recent dose 600 mg or more): supplemental dose of 600 mg by IV infusion over 35 minutes within 60 minutes after each plasmapheresis or plasma exchange
  • fresh frozen plasma infusion (most recent dose 300 mg or more): supplemental dose of 300 mg for each unit of fresh frozen plasma by IV infusion over 35 minutes, given 60 minutes prior to each 1 unit of fresh frozen plasma

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome, Atypical
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria

2.title: Black Box Warning
2.mono:
Intravenous (Solution)
Meningococcal infections, which may rapidly become life-threatening or fatal if not recognized and treated early, have been reported in patients treated with eculizumab. Comply with the most current Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommendations for meningococcal vaccination in patients with complement deficiencies. Immunize patients with a meningococcal vaccine at least 2 weeks prior to administering the first dose of eculizumab, unless the risks of delaying eculizumab therapy outweigh the risk of developing a meningococcal infection. Monitor patients for early signs of meningococcal infections and evaluate immediately if infection is suspected. Eculizumab is available only through a restricted program under a Risk Evaluation and Mitigation Strategy (REMS). Under the eculizumab REMS prescribers must enroll in the program. Enrollment in the eculizumab REMS program and additional information are available by telephone: 1-888-SOLIRIS (1-888-765-4747).

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• no current vaccination against Neisseria meningitidis, unless the risks of delaying treatment outweigh the risks of developing a meningococcal infection
  • unresolved serious Neisseria meningitidis infection

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Black Box Warning:
  • -- life-threatening and fatal meningococcal infections have been reported; monitoring recommended; discontinue use if undergoing treatment for serious meningococcal infections
  • Hematologic:
  • -- hemolysis may occur in patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria after discontinuation; monitoring recommended
  • -- thrombotic microangiopathy may occur in patients with atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome after discontinuation; monitoring recommended and consider reinstitution if occurs
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Aspergillus infections have been reported in immunocompromised and neutropenic patients
  • -- serious infection due to Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenza type b may occur, especially in children
  • -- give cautiously to patients with any systemic infection
  • -- anaphylaxis and other hypersensitivity reactions may occur; interruption may be necessary
  • Other:
  • -- infusion reactions may occur; interruption may be necessary

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Hypertension (adults, 17% to 59%; pediatrics, 22%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (adults, 32% to 47%; pediatrics, 20% to 40%), Nausea (12% to 40%), Vomiting (adults, 15% to 47%; pediatrics, 10% to 40%)
  • Hematologic:Anemia (17% to 35%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Backache (5% to 19%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (adults, 37% to 50%; pediatrics, 18%), Insomnia (10% to 24%)
  • Respiratory:Nasal congestion (21%), Nasopharyngitis (adults, 17% to 55%; pediatrics, 27%), Respiratory tract infection (adults, 5% to 40%; pediatrics, 25% to 40%)
  • Other:Fever (adults, 17% to 25%; pediatrics, 25% to 80%)
Serious
  • Hematologic:Leukopenia (12% to 24%)
  • Immunologic:Antibody development, Anti-eculizumab (1% to 3%)
  • Other:Infectious disease, Meningococcal infectious disease, Viral disease (2% (serious))

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Eculizumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds with high affinity to compliment protein C5, which inhibits its cleavage to C5a and C5b and prevents the generation of the terminal complement complex C5b-9. In patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), eculizumab inhibits terminal complement mediated intravascular hemolysis and in patients with acquired hemolytic uremic syndrome, eculizumab inhibits complement-mediated thrombotic microangiopathy.

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Exchange transfusion: 3660 mL/hr
  • Total body clearance: acquired hemolytic uremic syndrome, 14.6 mL/hr; paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria, 22 mL/hr

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono: Acquired hemolytic uremic syndrome (aHUS): 291 hours; aHUS (receiving plasma transfusion or plasma exchange): 1.26 hours; paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria: 272 +/- 82 hours

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • dilute required dose to a final concentration of 5 mg/mL by adding appropriate amounts of NS, 0.45% NaCl, D5W, or Ringer's injection
  • final infusion volume is 60 mL for 300 mg dose, 120 mL for 600 mg dose, 180 mL for 900 mg dose, and 240 mL for 1200 mg dose
  • allow admixture to adjust to room temperature (18 to 25 degrees C; 64 to 77 degrees F); do not heat in a microwave or any other heat source
  • admixed solutions are stable for 24 hours at 2 to 8 degrees C (36 to 46 degrees F) and at room temperature
  • do not administer by IV push or IV bolus injection
  • in adults administer via IV infusion over 35 minutes via gravity feed, a single-type pump, or an infusion pump; infusion may be slowed or stopped due to adverse reactions, but total infusion time should not exceed 2 hours
  • in pediatric patients administer via IV infusion over 1 to 4 hours via gravity feed, a single-type pump, or an infusion pump

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome: signs and symptoms of thrombotic microangiopathy reduction from baseline may indicate efficacy
  • paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria: reduction of signs and symptoms of hemolysis reduction from baseline may indicate efficacy
  • atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome: serial platelet count, serum LDL levels, and serum creatinine levels during treatment and for at least 12 weeks after discontinuation of therapy
  • paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria: serial serum LDH levels during treatment and for at least 8 weeks after discontinuation of therapy
  • early signs and symptoms of meningococcal infections, other infections
  • signs and symptoms of infusion reaction, for at least 1 hour following completion of infusion

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of meningococcal infection (eg, fever (103 degrees F or higher), rash, muscle aches, flu-like symptoms, eye sensitivity to light, confusion, headaches, nausea, vomiting, stiff neck or back) or any infection.
  • Advise patient that additional vaccine doses to prevent meningococcal, pneumococcal, or haemophilus influenza infections may be required during therapy.
  • Drug may cause headaches, back pain, diarrhea, nausea, nasopharyngitis, hypertension, and upper respiratory tract infections.
  • Counsel patient with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria to report signs/symptoms of hemolysis (eg, pain, jaundice, dark urine, dyspnea) after discontinuation.
  • Tell patient with atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome to report signs/symptoms of thrombotic microangiopathy (eg, mental status changes, angina, dyspnea, thrombosis) after discontinuation.
  • Advise patient to carry the Soliris(R) Patient Safety Card at all times during therapy and for at least 3 months after discontinuation.
